Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Multiphoton Polymerization with Optical Trap Assisted Nanopatterning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award provides funding to develop an innovative 3-D additive manufacturing process capable of producing uniform metal and polymer features with nanometer resolution for applications in optics, photonics, biomaterials and other areas. Here, we propose to combine the patterning resolution and scaling benefits provided by the recently developed optical trap assisted nanopatterning method with the 3-D additive capabilities of ultrafast multiphoton polymerization processing. However in order to achieve this goal, it is necessary to attain a deeper understanding of these processes and demonstrate the feasibility of such a combined approach. To this end, this proposal will focus on experimentally and numerically probing fundamental proof?]of?]principle questions related to the compatibility of ultrafast laser processing and polymer precursor solutions with optically trapped microspheres, and the ability to polymerize precursor solutions in the vicinity of microspheres without contamination or redeposition. Numerical studies will include finite difference time domain simulations for optical propagation through the liquid solution and polystyrene microspheres. Whereas, experiments will use both in situ imaging during laser processing and ex situ characterization to identify the material response.

If successful, this research will have a profound impact on a number of diverse application areas where multiscale and multifunctional 3-D architectures are needed to advance functionality, such as in photonic materials, optoelectronics, microfluidics, tissue engineering, etc. Broad dissemination in these areas through publications and international presentations will ensure researchers gain widespread benefit from our studies. But perhaps more importantly, the success of this research will provide a demonstration of feasibility that is necessary to secure funding through traditional vehicles in order to further develop this potentially transformative materials processing approach. Finally, we envision this research as a seed for an international collaboration between researchers at Princeton and University of Erlangen-Nurenberg, School of Advanced Optical Technologies (UEN-SAOT) in Germany for 3-D laser based manufacturing. To this end, funds have been allocated to support the travel to UEN-SAOT where the PIs will help train other researchers and students in this developing technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant provided funding to seed the the necessary proof of principle for an innovative 3-D nanoscale additive manufacturing process capable of producing uniform metal and polymer features with nanometer resolution for applications in optics, photonics, biomaterials and other areas. The ability to directly write sub-micron features on various substrates with high throughput, accuracy, and uniformity has become a key driver in the development of increasingly faster and smaller computer chips, which has led to the vast improvement in consumer electronics that we have known in the last decades.  Similarly, there is a great deal of expectation for creating nanoscale devices with applications in optics, photonics, biomaterials or even medicine. Due to their functions, such devices will be made out of a variety of materials like polymers, metals or even biological materials, will feature complex 3D geometries and may even need to be realized in situ. However, the well-established computer chips manufacturing technologies are often not compatible with the different types of materials needed, with non-flat substrates or objects with complex geometry, or with non-cleanroom environments.  Therefore, the development of these novel devices requires new, versatile fabrications techniques. The goal of this project is to address this need by laying the groundwork for new approaches in direct-write nanofabrication that can be used for various materials, topographies and environmental conditions, and even possibly in vivo.

 

At the heart of our method is the optical trap assisted nanopatterning (OTAN) method developed in our group.  However this method, which uses optically trapped and manipulated polystyrene beads as near field focusing objectives, was originally developed for us in 2D systems and our goal is to assess the opportunities and limitations in scaling this basic technology to 3D.  To this end, our project was quite successful as it provided a number of important proofs of principle.  These include demonstrating that the OTAN process can be used to create uniform nanoscale structures on non-planar surfaces, bead manipulation and positioning can be done in polymer precursor solutions, and parallel patterning on multi-level surfaces is possible.  These results have been published in leading scientific journals and disseminated to the greater research community.  But more importantly, these initial results establish potential for OTAN as a unique and viable 3D additive processing method.

 

The broader impact of this work is that it has not only laid the groundwork for further scientific and technological development in the nanotechnology arena, but it has initiated a number of student and outreach opportunities that have continued beyond the end of this project. We have hosted visiting students and REU students under this program and the PI has participated in various K-12 outreach activities including presenting demonstrations at local science museums and working with high school and junior high school students at the Princeton University Materials Academy.   

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2014
Modified by: Craig B Arnold
